message_1: A sample of a radioactive element has an initial activity of 2000 counts per minute. If the half-life of the element is 5 days, what would be its activity after 15 days?
message_2:
To find the activity of the radioactive element after 15 days, we can use the formula for radioactive decay:

Activity_final = Activity_initial * (1/2)^(time_elapsed / half_life)

where Activity_initial is the initial activity (2000 counts per minute), time_elapsed is the time that has passed (15 days), and half_life is the half-life of the element (5 days).

Activity_final = 2000 * (1/2)^(15 / 5)

Activity_final = 2000 * (1/2)^3

Activity_final = 2000 * (1/8)

Activity_final = 250 counts per minute

So, after 15 days, the activity of the radioactive element would be 250 counts per minute.
